channel.title: NPR Topics: News
channel.description: NPR news, audio, and podcasts. Coverage of breaking stories, national and world news, politics, business, science, technology, and extended coverage of major national and world events.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 NPR - For Personal Use Only

item.title: What to know about tonight's VP debate. And, a guide to discussing misinformation
item.description: JD Vance and Tim Walz will have their first vice presidential debate tonight as both parties aim to win over swing state voters. And, Israel invades Lebanon for the first time since 2006.
item.content:encoded:
JD Vance and Tim Walz will have their first vice presidential debate tonight as both parties aim to win over swing state voters. And, Israel invades Lebanon for the first time since 2006.

(Image credit: Maya Levin)
item.dc:creator: Brittney Melton

item.title: In Nevada, Latinos could pick the next president. They aren't sold on either candidate
item.description: In Nevada, 1 in 5 potential voters are Latino. That is a voting bloc with a lot of political power in a state where elections are won by a few percentage points. And campaigns are paying attention.
item.content:encoded:
In Nevada, 1 in 5 potential voters are Latino. That is a voting bloc with a lot of political power in a state where elections are won by a few percentage points. And campaigns are paying attention.

(Image credit: Franco Ordonez)
item.dc:creator: Franco Ordoñez

item.title: 5 things to know about Mexico's first female president
item.description: Claudia Sheinbaum is a 62-year old environmental scientist who left academia on a political trajectory that took her from a local mayor, to running Mexico City, to winning the presidency with nearly 60 percent of the vote.
item.content:encoded:
Claudia Sheinbaum is a 62-year old environmental scientist who left academia on a political trajectory that took her from a local mayor, to running Mexico City, to winning the presidency with nearly 60 percent of the vote.

(Image credit: Hector Vivas)
item.dc:creator: Emily Green

item.title: Israel begins ground offensive in Lebanon
item.description: The Israeli military pressed its ground incursion into southern Lebanon on Tuesday, calling the operations “limited incursions” that are targeting Hezbollah militants.
item.content:encoded:
The Israeli military pressed its ground incursion into southern Lebanon on Tuesday, calling the operations “limited incursions” that are targeting Hezbollah militants.

(Image credit: Maya Levin)
item.dc:creator: Daniel Estrin

item.title: Vance and Walz are both veterans. Here's what it means to have a vet VP
item.description: For the first time since 1996, both major parties have picked a veteran for vice president -- a fact that some veterans' groups are hoping it leads to greater understanding of military and vet issues.
item.content:encoded:
For the first time since 1996, both major parties have picked a veteran for vice president -- a fact that some veterans' groups are hoping it leads to greater understanding of military and vet issues.

(Image credit: Justin Sullivan/Getty Images; Drew Hallowell/Getty Images)
item.dc:creator: Quil Lawrence

item.title: Justice Department No. 3 official pledges to fight hate crimes, fueled by personal story
item.description: The Justice Department's third-in-command talked about the department's pledge to fight hate crimes, and shared he was close in age to Matthew Shepard, whose death inspired a federal law helping to prosecute people fueled by hate.
item.content:encoded:
The Justice Department's third-in-command talked about the department's pledge to fight hate crimes, and shared he was close in age to Matthew Shepard, whose death inspired a federal law helping to prosecute people fueled by hate.

(Image credit: Mandel Ngan)
item.dc:creator: Carrie Johnson

item.title: In battle over its past, China wages courtroom fight in California
item.description: As China marks 75 years of Communist rule, a battle is playing out over a Party insider's old notebooks and letters stored at Stanford University.
item.content:encoded: As China marks 75 years of Communist rule, a battle is playing out over a Party insider's old notebooks and letters stored at Stanford University.
item.dc:creator: John Ruwitch

item.title: Photos: As Jimmy Carter celebrates his 100th birthday, a look through the decades
item.description: Former President Jimmy Carter is turning 100. Here are images from notable events or parts of his life, both during his presidency and after.
item.content:encoded:
Former President Jimmy Carter is turning 100. Here are images from notable events or parts of his life, both during his presidency and after.

(Image credit: Paul Hennessy)
item.dc:creator: James Doubek

item.title: Poll workers can be hard to find. In Nebraska, election officials can draft them
item.description: Nebraska has a unique solution to staffing elections: It allows counties to draft workers. Omaha's Douglas County is the only one to regularly use it. Here’s how the jury duty-like system works.
item.content:encoded:
Nebraska has a unique solution to staffing elections: It allows counties to draft workers. Omaha's Douglas County is the only one to regularly use it. Here’s how the jury duty-like system works.

(Image credit: Terry A. Ratzlaff for NPR)
item.dc:creator: Kassidy Arena

item.title: How young Republicans and Democrats are whipping up votes in key districts
item.description: As the presidential race ramps up in Georgia, one vital voting demographic is mobilizing and hoping to impact the race: young people.
item.content:encoded:
As the presidential race ramps up in Georgia, one vital voting demographic is mobilizing and hoping to impact the race: young people.

(Image credit: Nydia Blas for NPR)
item.dc:creator: Mary Louise Kelly
